column2: Full Name
column14: Course Outcomes: all

column1: PHARM 327 (Winter 2016 LEC B1 B2 SEM J1)
column2: PHARM 327 Wi16 - NUTRITION Combined LEC SEM Wi16
column14: By the end of this course, students will be able to know and understand nutritional terminology, what a healthy diet is, macro/micro nutrient requirements, and the role of nutrients in health and disease states (obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular, osteoporosis, gut diseases, cancer, autoimmune-inflammatory diseases, and metabolic syndrome).
column15: By the time students finish the course, they should be able to explain their learning and knowledge in the area of nutrition to others. This will be tested by multiple choices and short-answer exam questions.
column16: By the end of this course, students will be able to develop an appreciation of the fundamental importance of nutrition.

column2: PHARM 497 ENDOCRINE (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

column2: PHARM 497 ENDOCRINE (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

column2: PHARM 497 ENDOCRINE (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: Identify the main anatomy components of the endocrine system.
column15: Describe the physiological effects of the following: adrenal, thyroid, parathyroid, neurohypophyseal and pancreatic hormones.
column16: Describe the epidemiology, etiology, and risk factors of endocrine disorders.
column17: Describe the pathophysiology of endocrine disorders, including clinical presentation, symptomatology, and long-term health consequences.
column18: Recognize the main structural features of drugs used to manage endocrine disorders.
column19: Explain the pharmacologic effects of drugs used in the management of endocrine disorders.
column20: Describe pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles to the treatment of endocrine disorders.
column21: Describe the specific laboratory tests used in the diagnosis and monitoring of endocrine disorders.
column22: Describe the therapeutic approach incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments to the prevention, treatment and management of endocrine disorders, including use of specific target drugs for condition as well as alternative therapies (dose, route of administration, length of therapy, monitoring parameters).
column23: Recognize and understand the appropriate acute management strategies for patients with diabetes, including travel, exercise and acute illness.
column24: Describe the toxicity of medications used in the management of endocrine disorders.
column25: Identify ethical and cultural issues surrounding endocrine disorders.
column26: Identify the role and the responsibility of the pharmacist within the course of the disease state and its therapy.
column27: Identify applicable health system resources.
column28: Identify and resolve clinically significant drug interactions.
column29: Select appropriate treatment for special groups (e.g., pediatrics, geriatrics, pregnant or lactating women).
column30: Apply concepts and knowledge of medicinal chemistry, pharmacology, and therapeutic principles for pharmacologic management of endocrine disorders.
column31: Identify actual and potential drug-related problems associated with pharmacologic management of endocrine disorders.
column32: Develop a patient care plan related to the care of patients with endocrine disorders, including appropriate monitoring and documentation.
column33: Identify when to inform physicians and caregivers if there are danger signs apparent in the assessment.
column34: Identify and retrieve appropriate sources of information needed to resolve drug related problems.
column35: Use the principles of evidence-based medicine to critically evaluate the validity and applicability of information from various literature resources.
column36: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for patients experiencing of the conditions of primary focus.
column37: Develop an appreciation of the interdisciplinary nature of patient care.
column38: Accept responsibility for keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drugs.

column14: Explain the importance of stress management in professional life
column15: Understand purpose for talking with a patient about new medication vs ongoing therapy
column16: Describe the elements of a medication history
column17: Compare and contrast concordance, compliance, and adherence frameworks
column18: Identify supportive communication techniques to assess patients medication to assess med taking behaviours and detect barriers
column19: Compare and contrast intentional and unintentional medication taking behaviours

column21: Appreciate patient perspective in living with hearing loss.
column22: Differentiate strategies to communicate with patients with hearing and hearing loss.
column23: Identify communication challenges associated with providing care to a patient whose first language is not English.
column24: Understand effective patient education skills
column25: Describe the appropriate process for working with an interpreter in a healthcare setting.
column26: Understand the complexity of communicating risk to patients
column27: Identify several strategies for effectively communicating risk
column28: Describe the SBAR technique for communicating with other healthcare professionals
column29: Identify a process to manage emotional consults
column30: Identify core principles and key skills of motivational interviewing
column31: Practice self-care activities to manage stress in professional life

column33: Develop strategies to help patients overcome barriers to taking their medications
column34: Recognize verbal and nonverbal cues signaling anger, conflict, and lack of trust
column35: Demonstrate appropriate techniques for dealing with anger, conflict, and lack of trust
column36: Communicate effectively with people with vision or hearing loss
column37: Communicate effectively using a translator
column38: Select and integrate communication techniques to effectively communicate risk to patients
column39: Select and integrate communication techniques to effectively communicate with other healthcare professionals.
column40: Engage in effective partnerships with their patients to support positive behaviour changes
column41: Perform rapid assessments of their patients readiness for change
column42: Help patients to increase motivation and overcome barriers to change
column43: Recognize prior encounters with the patient (if applicable)
column44: Provide tailored information (verbal and written)
column45: Provide clear patient information in manageable chunks
column46: Relate explanation to patients experiences and understandings
column47: Check for patient understanding of medication information
column48: Invite follow-up includes who, how, and when
column49: Establish organization and flow while taking a full medication history
column50: Listen and adapt to patient cues in differing patient scenarios
column52: Accept responsibility for communicating professionally through both student and professional career
column53: Accept responsibility for providing patient care
column54: Foster curiosity to understand and appreciate your patients unique life experience
column55: Advocate for pharmacists role in monitoring medication therapy at the medication refill

column2: PHARM 342 Wi16 - DRUG USE & PATIENT CARE Combined LAB LEC SEM Wi16
column14: Identify the basic process requirements in utilizing the Patient Care Process: a. Construct a patient care database b. Identify the drug related problem c. Manage a patient care profile electronically
column15: Explain the basic concepts and principles applicable to professional responsibilities in the drug use control process and patient care interactions.
column16: Identify federal and provincial pharmacy legislation with respect to the appropriate handling of drug products
column17: Identify legal requirements when accepting/receiving written & verbal prescriptions.
column18: Discuss how the medication-dispensing process intersects with the patient care process, and the respective roles of pharmacists, pharmacy students and pharmacy technicians and pharmacy technician students.
column19: Identify and document potential medication prescribing errors in written and verbal prescriptions.
column20: Apply relevant components of the Patient Care Process model to pharmacy practice.
column21: Demonstrate effective communication in clarifying prescription orders, providing drug information, documentation of errors and interacting with health care professionals and patients.
column22: Utilize critical thinking in the problem solving process.
column23: Accurately process written and verbal prescriptions, meeting all legal and technical requirements for medications.
column24: Demonstrate competency of the prescription processing software (KROLL).
column25: Function efficiently within the simulated pharmacy, both independently and within a group.
column26: Complete an accurate patient record by gathering medication history and other relevant information.
column27: Demonstrate a responsible, caring, and professional attitude towards the profession of pharmacy, students, patients, and health care professionals.

PHARM 387 PEDIATRICS / GERIATRICS (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

column2: PHARM 387 PEDIATRICS / GERIATRICS (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: Describe the pharmacoepidemiology, including prescription, non-prescription medication, and natural health products.
column15: Describe risks for adverse drug events in pediatric and geriatric patients, and explain why they are more susceptible to adverse events.
column16: Identify and describe age-appropriate communication strategies.
column17: Describe the role that culture, religion, and ethnicity may play in health and decision making.
column18: Identify controversial health issues involving pediatric and geriatric populations
column19: Identify and discuss some of the challenges involved in treating the pediatric population; including communication strategies, presentation of illness and the management and administration of medications to infants and children.
column20: Discuss the importance of medication safety and identify measures used to ensure safe medication practices
column21: Review pediatric toxicology and discuss preventative interventions that pharmacists can promote to patients or utilize in their practice to minimize pediatric toxicological poisonings or incidences.
column22: Discuss basic neonatal care and challenges including premature birth.
column23: Explain how pharmacokinetic parameters are different in infants and children versus adults.
column24: Explain the significant differences in physiologic parameters between adolescents, children, toddlers and infants; including premature babies, and neonates
column25: Identify and discuss appropriate management plans for common pediatric illnesses such as teething and fevers.
column26: Identify and discuss appropriate management plans for common pediatric gastrointestinal illnesses (e.g. vomiting, diarrhea, dehydration, colic, and constipation).
column27: Discuss presentation and treatment for common pulmonary pediatric illnesses; Croup and Bronchiolitis.
column28: Describe the various forms of pediatric abuse and discuss the Child, Youth and Family Enhancement Act and the responsibilities that are associated with the Act
column29: Discuss the management and implications involved with a diagnosis of autism.
column30: Be able to triage patients in a community setting and refer them to medical attention as appropriate.
column31: Apply applicable pharmacokinetic parameters to monitor patients and assess appropriate use of medications.
column32: Apply knowledge and skills to establish safe and effective drug use.
column33: Utilize when available an evidence based approach to therapeutic management of pediatric and geriatric patients.
column34: Identify sources of information needed to solve drug related problems specific to the populations being studied.
column35: Identify and be able to recommend aids to assist in medication management and administration.
column36: Empathize with children, older adults, and caregivers regarding challenging decision-making.
column37: Take and defend a position on a controversy related to pediatrics and geriatrics using evidence-based arguments.
column38: Collaborate with peers to prepare and present an argument.
column39: Communicate position through oral presentation and debate.
column40: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for and response to pediatric and geriatric patients
column41: Develop an appreciation of the comprehensive, interdisciplinary nature of patient care for children and older adults
column42: Appreciate the challenges related to decision making and advocacy in grey areas of clinical practice and health.

column2: PHARM 387 PEDIATRICS / GERIATRICS (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: Define and be able to use the following terms in a clinical context: geriatrics, gerontology, elderly, aging, frailty.
column15: Describe common stereotypes and biases toward aging in our western society.
column16: Explain the demographics of aging, and how that may impact society and the healthcare system.
column17: Briefly describe the psychosocial aspects of aging and be able to explain the role of the pharmacist in dealing with these aspects.
column18: Describe the physiologic alterations associated with normal aging that modify drug response in the elderly patient.
column19: Describe the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic changes associated with aging, and apply the principles to medications commonly used in geriatrics.
column20: List the most common chronic diseases and causes of death in seniors.
column21: Contrast disease presentation between the young adult and the elderly adult.
column22: Identify medications that are considered inappropriate or high risk in older adults and explain why they are inappropriate or high risk.
column23: Describe how criteria were developed to classify medications as appropriate or inappropriate in seniors.
column24: Define polypharmacy and underutilization in terms of medications in seniors.
column25: Contrast the presentation of adverse events in the elderly compared to the young adult.
column26: Describe the impact of falls on the senior population.
column27: Identify risk factors for falls in older individuals.
column28: Describe appropriate interventions for falls.
column29: Contrast how a geriatric syndrome is different than a disease state.
column30: List the common geriatric syndromes.
column31: Discuss the role of the pharmacist in medication management of seniors.
column32: Identify methods of appropriately communicating with older adults who are hard of hearing.
column33: Describe the role of the pharmacist in working with home care.
column34: Identify appropriate home care supports for a given patient.
column35: Categorize the types of abuse commonly suffered by seniors.
column36: Describe the role of the pharmacist in reducing elder abuse.
column37: Explain the demographics of the pediatric population in society, and explain how that may impact our role as pharmacists. (e.g. improvement of childhood illnesses, trend towards chronic disease management)
column38: Identify and discuss some of the challenges involved in treating the pediatric population; including communication strategies, presentation of illness and the management and administration of medications to infants and children.
column39: Discuss the importance of medication safety and identify measures used to ensure safe medication practices
column40: Apply knowledge and skills to establish safe and effective drug use.
column41: Utilize when available an evidence based approach to therapeutic management of pediatric and geriatric patients.
column42: Identify sources of information needed to solve drug related problems specific to the populations being studied.
column43: Identify and be able to recommend aids to assist in medication management and administration.
column44: Empathize with children, older adults, and caregivers regarding challenging decision-making.
column45: Take and defend a position on a controversy related to pediatrics and geriatrics using evidence-based arguments.
column46: Collaborate with peers to prepare and present an argument.
column47: Communicate position through oral presentation and debate.
column48: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for and response to pediatric and geriatric patients
column49: Develop an appreciation of the comprehensive, interdisciplinary nature of patient care for children and older adults
column50: Appreciate the challenges related to decision making and advocacy in grey areas of clinical practice and health.

column14: Comprehend one and two compartmental models, including the underlying reasons for the appearance of more than one compartment in a plasma concentration vs. time profile.

column16: Grasp the concept of steady state and its dependency on half-life in relation to constant intravenous infusion and repeated dose administration.
column17: Understand the relationship between organ clearance and total body clearance, and detail the mechanisms involved in renal and hepatic drug clearance of a particular drug.

column22: Become proactive in including and considering concepts of therapeutic drug monitoring in practice skills.

PHARM 382 Wi16 - PROV/CDN HEALTHCARE Combined LEC Wi16
column14: The student will be able to describe the components of the healthcare system and how they interrelate as it pertains to the delivery of healthcare services in Canada and more specifically,Alberta.
column15: The student will be able to list the names and describe the function of relevant health professional associations, government agencies, advocacy groups, and private sector players as it pertains to thedelivery of health care in Canada with particular emphasis on organizations that impact theprofession of pharmacy.
column16: The student will be able to describe some of the strategies that pharmacists and pharmacy organizations use to influence others within the Canadian healthcare system.
column17: The student will develop an appreciation for the recommendations made by current (i.e. within the past 10 years) studies, reports and reviews of the Canadian and Alberta health systems.
column18: The student will develop an appreciation of the different pharmacy service delivery models in different provincial and relevant international jurisdictions.

column14: The student will be able to identify and debate key issues and challenges facing the Canadian healthcare system.

column2: PHARM 362 PHARMACY LAWS AND ETHICS (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: Define and explain the following ethical concepts: beneficence, nonmaleficence, autonomy, and informed consent.
column15: Outline the pharmacists ethical obligations.
column16: Describe the court system in the Province of Alberta.
column17: Explain the process of disciplinary action by the Alberta College of Pharmacists.
column18: Describe the course of action taken by the Alberta College of Pharmacists on the issue of substance abuse by pharmacists.
column19: Apply legal and ethical principles to issues that may occur in practice.
column20: Argue both sides of an ethical or legal issue using ethical and legal principles derived from statutes, case law, bioethics literature and the Alberta College of Pharmacists Code of Ethics
column21: Analyze an ethical or legal issue by determining principles involved, clarifying facts, prioritizing principles, assessing alternatives, determining duty and justifying decisions.
column22: Apply actions that a pharmacist can take in order to avoid legal liability (e.g. avoiding medication errors, proper documentation, etc.).
column23: Utilize the problem-solving method (e.g. identify the problem, identify possible alternatives, evaluate the alternatives, choose the best course of action, and defend the action) to integrate ethical and legal principles, and professionalism into pharmacy practice.
column24: Apply actions that a pharmacist can take to avoid ethical breaches and professional discipline
column25: Demonstrate ability to distinguish an ethical problem from a legal one, and to identify points of intersection, divergence or confrontation.
column26: Participate in debating a legal/ethical issue with oneâ€™s peers
column27: Demonstrate awareness of the demands of professional, ethical and legal responsibility.
column28: Accept the professional responsibility to act for the benefit of the patient.
column29: Demonstrate caring and respect for others.
column30: Accept possible differences between personal values, morals and rights versus professional obligations and ethics.
column31: Be sensitive to ethical/legal issues that arise in contemporary pharmacy practice.

column14: Explain the elements of negligence.

column21: Explain the legal implications of a personal directives and enduring powers of attorney.
column22: Describe the unique health care issues faced by the Aboriginal Peoples of Canada.
column23: Describe the legal and professional rules governing medical aid in dying.
column24: Describe the defenses to a negligence or malpractice lawsuit.
column25: Explain how compensation for a negligence lawsuit is determined.
column26: Describe the course of action taken by the Alberta College of Pharmacists on the issue of substance abuse by pharmacists.

column1: PHARM 397 (Fall 2016 LEC A1 A2 SEM E1 E2)
column2: PHARM 397 Fa16 - VALUES, UROLOGY & NEPHROLOGY Combined LEC SEM Fa16
column14: Describe the therapeutic approach incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments for electrolyte disorders, acid-base disorders, acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, nephrolithiasis, and LUTS including use of specific target drugs for the condition as well as alternative therapies (dose, route of administration, length of therapy, monitoring parameters).
column15: Identify medications which can cause renal toxicity, and describe the appropriate management.
column16: Describe the epidemiology, etiology, and risk factors of the following: renal disorders including acute kidney injury, nephrolithiasis, Chronic Kidney Disease, and LUTS.
column17: Describe the anatomy of the kidney, ureters, bladder, and urethra.
column18: Describe the physiology of the ureters, bladder and urethra including a general outline of bladder function and micturition.
column19: Describe the physiology of the kidney including regulation of glomerular filtration, sodium/water balance, fluid balance, acid-base balance as well as other electrolytes, tubular reabsorption and secretion.
column20: Explain the major functions and consequences of disturbances of: sodium, potassium, magnesium, calcium, and phosphate.
column21: Describe the etiology, pathophysiology, clinical presentation, and compensatory mechanism of the four acid-base disorders.
column22: Describe the societal and economic impact of LUTS
column23: Describe the pathophysiology of renal disorders including acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, nephrolithiasis, and incontinence including clinical presentation and symptomatology and long term health consequences
column24: Describe the principles of the various Renal Replacement Therapies (Hemodialysis, Peritoneal Dialysis, and Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy).
column25: Explain the effects of drugs used in the management of electrolyte disorders, acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, nephrolithiasis, and LUTS.
column26: Explain and interpret pertinent serum chemistry laboratory values, as well as specific laboratory tests used in the diagnosis and monitoring of acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, nephrolithiasis, and lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).
column27: Identify the role and the responsibility of the pharmacist within the course of the disease state and its therapy.
column28: For each of the conditions described the student should:
column29: Identify the presenting signs and symptoms of electrolyte disorders, acid-base disorders, acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, nephrolithiasis, and LUTS and describe criteria used to make the diagnosis.
column30: Discuss the therapeutic options, including risks and benefits, and medication and alternative therapy choices.
column31: Identify appropriate monitoring parameters.
column32: Recommend appropriate changes to therapy based on patient outcomes and monitoring parameters.
column33: Apply concepts and knowledge of pharmacology and therapeutic principles in selecting and monitoring drug therapy for the management of electrolyte disorders (hyper/hyponatremia, hyper/hypokalemia), acid-base disorders, acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease nephrolithiasis, and LUTS.
column34: Assess lab data in order to manage medical condition and medication regimen.
column35: Describe how to triage a given patient in a community setting and identify when to refer them to medical attention as appropriate.
column36: Design pharmaceutical care plans including alternatives (drug, non-drug), recommendations, implementation, monitoring and follow up for patients with electrolyte disorders, acute kidney injury, nephrolithiasis, and LUTS
column37: Assess fluid balance based on medical history as well as presenting signs and symptoms, and recommend appropriate management of the patient.
column38: Calculate creatinine clearance and adjust doses for medications that are renally eliminated.
column39: Identify when to inform physicians and caregivers if there are danger signs apparent in the assessment.
column40: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for patients experiencing the conditions of primary focus.
column41: Work effectively within the healthcare team.
column42: Develop an appreciation of the interdisciplinary nature of patient care.
column43: Accept responsibility for keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drugs

column2: PHARM 347 Fa16 - HEMATOLOGY Combined LEC Fa16
PHARM 347 Fa16 - HEMATOLOGY Combined LEC Fa16
column14: Explain the anatomy of blood supply and the lymphatic system of the human.
column15: Identify applicable health system resources
column16: Identify the role and the responsibility of the pharmacist within the course of the disease state and its therapy.
column17: Describe the epidemiology, etiology, and risk factors of the conditions of primary focus.
column18: Identify ethical issues surrounding treatment of the conditions of primary focus.
column19: Discuss the physiology of the blood supply and lymphatic system including the composition and properties of blood, blood groups and selected functions of blood.
column20: Describe the pathophysiology of the conditions of primary focus, including clinical presentation and symptomatology and long term health consequences.
column21: Explain the effects of drugs used in the management of the conditions of primary focus.
column22: Describe the specific laboratory tests used in the diagnosis and monitoring of the conditions of primary focus.
column23: Describe the mechanisms, efficacy, side effect profiles and role of each of the following drugs or drug classes: i. Anticoagulants ii. Antiplatelets iii. Fibrinolytics iv. Antifibrinolytics v. Stimulating Factors vi. Iron products
column24: Describe the therapeutic approach incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments including use of specific target drugs for condition as well as alternative therapies (dose, route of administration, length of therapy, monitoring parameters)
column25: Utilize self-directed learning abilities
column26: Apply pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles to the treatment of the conditions of primary focus.
column27: Manage clinically significant drug interactions with drugs used to treat the conditions of primary focus.
column28: Select appropriate treatment for special groups (pediatrics, elderly, pregnancy, lactation).

column14: Identify ethical issues in the management of mental health conditions.

column14: Describe the components of the healthcare system and how they interrelate as it pertains to the delivery of healthcare services in Canada and more specifically, Alberta.
column15: List the names and describe the function of relevant health professional associations, government agencies, advocacy groups, and private sector players as it pertains to the delivery of health care in Canada with particular emphasis on organizations that impact the profession of pharmacy.
column16: Describe some of the strategies that pharmacists and pharmacy organizations use to influence others within the Canadian healthcare system.
column17: Identify and debate key issues and challenges facing the Canadian healthcare system.
column18: Develop and debate solutions to some of the challenges facing the Canadian healthcare system with emphasis on how pharmacists and pharmacies can be a part of those solutions.
column19: Develop an appreciation for the recommendations made by current (i.e. within the past 10 years) studies, reports and reviews of the Canadian and Albertan health systems.
column20: Develop an appreciation of the different pharmacy service delivery models in different provincial and relevant international jurisdictions.

column14: Identify ethical issues surrounding treatment of the conditions of primary focus
column15: Identify the role and the responsibility of the pharmacist within the course of the disease state and its therapy.
column16: Identify applicable health system resources
column17: Describe the pathophysiology of the conditions of primary focus including clinical presentation and symptomatology and long term health consequences.
column18: Explain various basic cardiovascular measurements including: Heart sounds, Blood Pressure, Heart Rate, CXR, ECG, Ejection fraction
column19: Describe medicinal chemistry, pharmacology and therapeutic principles applicable to selecting and monitoring drug therapy for the management of the conditions of primary focus.
column20: Describe pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles applicable to the treatment of the conditions of primary focus.
column21: Describe the epidemiology, etiology, and risk factors of the conditions of primary focus.
column22: Explain the anatomy of the heart and great blood vessels.
column23: Discuss the physiology of the blood supply, lymphatic system and cardiovascular system of the human body.
column24: Explain the effects of drugs used in the management of the conditions of primary focus.
column25: Describe the specific laboratory tests used in the diagnosis and monitoring of the conditions of primary focus
column26: Describe the therapeutic approach incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments of the conditions of primary focus including use of specific target drugs forcondition as well as alternative therapies (dose, route of administration, length of therapy,monitoring parameters)
column27: Describe how to manage the toxicity of cardiac medications
column28: Describe the societal and economic impact of the conditions of primary focus
column29: Design pharmaceutical care plans including alternatives (drug, non-drug, referral,reassurance), recommendations, implementation, monitoring and follow up for patients with the conditions of primary focus.
column30: Identify actual and potential drug related problems relating the conditions of primary focus and in various patient cases.
column31: Manage clinically significant drug interactions with drugs used to treat the conditions of primary focus.
column32: Make rational, safe and effective drug treatment decisions for therapy, evaluation and monitoring based on an integrated knowledge of therapeutics, medicinal chemistry, and pharmacology.
column33: Utilize an evidence-based approach to therapeutic management of the conditions of primary focus.
column34: Identify and locate sources of information needed to solve drug related problems.
column35: Critically evaluate the appropriateness and reliability of information from literature resources.
column36: Synthesize information gained from various literature resources to solve problems or make recommendations.
column37: Develop and practice skills for measuring blood pressure and heart rate.
column38: Utilize self-directed learning abilities.
column39: Work effectively in a healthcare team.
column40: Obtain a relevant history from a patient
column41: Review the presenting signs and symptoms of the conditions of primary focus and describe criteria used to make the diagnosis and to be able to relate the severity of the disease
column42: Discuss the therapeutic options with patient, including risks and benefits, and medication and alternative therapy choices
column43: Apply and demonstrate appropriate counseling and communication with patients
column44: Follow appropriate monitoring parameters
column45: Recommend appropriate changes to therapy based on patient outcomes and monitoring parameters
column46: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for patients experiencing the conditions of primary focus.
column47: Develop an appreciation of the interdisciplinary nature of patient care.
column48: Accept responsibility for keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drugs.

column2: PHARM 342 Wi17 - DRUG USE & PATIENT CARE Combined LAB LEC SEM Wi17
column4: Pharmacy Practice,, BSc in Pharmacy, 1st year
column14: Identify the basic process requirements in utilizing the Patient Care Process:
column15: a. Construct a patient care database
column16: b. Identify the drug related problem
column17: c. Manage a patient care profile electronically
column18: Explain the basic concepts and principles applicable to professional responsibilities in the drug use control process and patient care interactions.
column19: Identify federal and provincial pharmacy legislation with respect to the appropriate handling of drug products and practicing within the professions scope.
column20: Identify legal requirements when accepting/receiving written & verbal prescriptions.
column21: For each component in the patient care process, describe the related activities and responsibilities of pharmacists, pharmacy students, interns, and pharmacy technicians.
column22: Discuss how the medication-dispensing process intersects with the patient care process, and the respective roles of pharmacists, pharmacy students and pharmacy technicians and pharmacy technician students.
column23: Identify and document potential medication prescribing errors in written and verbal prescriptions.
column24: Apply concepts of third party billing and prescription pricing in the drug use process.
column25: Recognize issues surrounding drug diversion and security.
column26: Demonstrate an introductory level of adverse drug reporting and management.
column27: Relate the concepts of the culture of patient safety to the drug use process.
column28: Apply relevant components of the Patient Care Process model to pharmacy practice.
column29: Demonstrate effective communication in clarifying prescription orders, providing drug information, documentation of errors and interacting with health care professionals and patients.
column30: Utilize critical thinking in the problem solving process.
column31: Accurately process written and verbal prescriptions, meeting all legal and technical requirements for medications.
column32: Demonstrate competency of the prescription processing software (KROLL).
column33: Function efficiently within the simulated pharmacy, both independently and within a group.
column34: Complete an accurate patient record by gathering medication history and other relevant information.
column35: Document search process for drug information questions, citing references used.
column36: Communicate effectively when having a dialogue with a simulated patient and other health care practitioners
column37: Demonstrate a responsible, caring, and professional attitude towards the profession of pharmacy, students, patients, and health care professionals.

column14: This module has been designed to familiarize pharmacy students with basic principles of diagnostic imaging, with emphasis on the use of radiation and radioactive drugs and contrast agents in medical diagnosis and therapy. The biological effects of radiation are presented from the viewpoint of a pharmacist's perspective as a health sciences team member.
column15: To indicate the levels of radiation dose received from common radiopharmaceutical diagnostic procedures and the inherent dangers with contrast materials and to place these into a benefit vs. risk concept.
column16: To acquaint students with basic physical fundamentals regarding concepts of radioactivity, rates and types of radioactive decay; units of radiation; biological effects of radiation â€“ toxicity and therapy; free radical formation and detoxification; diagnostic imaging techniques, instrumentation, and utilization of radiopharmaceuticals.
column17: To consider the various types of radiation and their characteristics and interactions with matter from the viewpoint of how these factors: Influence the utility of different radiations for clinical diagnosis or for therapy; Can present a health hazard from improper use or handling; Determine the methods of radiation detection and measurement
column18: To present the basic principles underlying the biological effects observed with exposure to various levels of radioactivity.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: To develop a basic understanding of the contemporary diagnostic imaging modalities, including nuclear medicine imaging, x-ray, CT, ultrasound, and MRI, and an understanding of the nature of the clinical information provided by each modality
column15: This course will provide general knowledge regarding diagnostic imaging and radioactivity, and will allow the pharmacist to place a proper perspective on such common concerns in a community as: Radiation safety in general; Biological hazards of radioactive material and installations utilizing radioactivity (eg. xray units) in hospitals and in the community; Risk â€“ benefit concepts in diagnostic imaging; General familiarity with imaging techniques/underlying principles.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: This module has been designed to familiarize pharmacy students with basic principles of diagnostic imaging, with emphasis on the use of radiation and radioactive drugs and contrast agents in medical diagnosis and therapy. The biological effects of radiation are presented from the viewpoint of a pharmacist's perspective as a health sciences team member.
column15: To illustrate the rationale for the use of radioactive drugs and contrast agents for diagnosis by discussing: the various agents presently available from commercial suppliers; the physiological basis of their utility and clinical applications; their formulation and manufacture; methods of quality control and dispensing and inventory control. The use of radioactive drugs for therapy will be examined.
column16: This course will provide a basis for further training (either formally or on-the-job) which will provide the expertise for safe and effective handling, preparation and dispensing of radiopharmaceuticals and maintaining proper quality control and inventory.
column17: To indicate the levels of radiation dose received from common radiopharmaceutical diagnostic procedures and the inherent dangers with contrast materials and to place these into a benefit vs. risk concept.
column18: To acquaint students with basic physical fundamentals regarding concepts of radioactivity, rates and types of radioactive decay; units of radiation; biological effects of radiation â€“ toxicity and therapy; free radical formation and detoxification; diagnostic imaging techniques, instrumentation, and utilization of radiopharmaceuticals.
column19: To consider the various types of radiation and their characteristics and interactions with matter from the viewpoint of how these factors: Influence the utility of different radiations for clinical diagnosis or for therapy; Can present a health hazard from improper use or handling; Determine the methods of radiation detection and measurement
column20: To present the basic principles underlying the biological effects observed with exposure to various levels of radioactivity.
column21: To illustrate "radiopharmaceutical kits", and radionuclide generators for daily preparation of short-lived radiopharmaceuticals in a hospital.
column22: To develop a basic understanding of the contemporary diagnostic imaging modalities, including nuclear medicine imaging, x-ray, CT, ultrasound, and MRI, and an understanding of the nature of the clinical information provided by each modality
column23: This course will provide general knowledge regarding diagnostic imaging and radioactivity, and will allow the pharmacist to place a proper perspective on such common concerns in a community as: Radiation safety in general; Biological hazards of radioactive material and installations utilizing radioactivity (eg. xray units) in hospitals and in the community; Risk â€“ benefit concepts in diagnostic imaging; General familiarity with imaging techniques/underlying principles.
column24: Following this course, students should be able to interpret the labels on radiopharmaceuticals; perform simple calculations related to radioactive decay.
column25: This course will provide pharmacists with fundamental knowledge of contemporary clinical imaging modalities, including the use of radiopharmaceuticals and contrast agents in clinical diagnosis and therapy. Such a basic understanding will enable pharmacists, as members of a Health Team, to communicate knowledgeably with physicians, nurses, technicians and patients regarding the use of various imaging techniques. Emphasis will be placed on radiopharmaceuticals and contrast agents used with these procedures. The use of radioactive materials for in vitro and in vivo tests, and for radiation therapy, will be addressed. An understanding of the general principles underlying the biologic effects of various levels of radiation will assist the pharmacist in allaying patients' fears and misapprehensions regarding radioactivity.

column15: This course will provide general knowledge regarding diagnostic imaging and radioactivity, and will allow the pharmacist to place a proper perspective on such common concerns in a community as: Radiation safety in general; Biological hazards of radioactive material and installations utilizing radioactivity (eg. xray units) in hospitals and in the community; Risk â€“ benefit concepts in diagnostic imaging; General familiarity with imaging techniques/underlying principles.

column14: Demonstrate an understanding of key concepts in pharmacokinetics and therapeutic drug monitoring and apply pharmacokinetic principles to resolve drug therapy problems and optimize pharmacotherapy outcomes.
column15: Apply acquired therapeutic knowledge to confidently and competently manage medication therapy (including monitoring and follow-up) for patients with both the common disease states covered and those beyond, even if complex interplay between disease states exists.
column16: Demonstrate critical thinking, therapeutic knowledge, and the use of a therapeutic thought process (patient care process) in prioritizing and resolving a patientâ€™s drug related problems, making appropriate recommendations related to ambiguous medication-related issues and those where evidence is limited or contradictory.
column17: Develop and defend a detailed care plan (with supporting chart documentation) to resolve and/or prevent drug related problems, applying principles of evidence-based medicine.
column18: Effectively translate therapeutic knowledge to patients with complex care issues and/or those of a sensitive nature that present challenges in communication, in a variety of settings.
column19: Demonstrate the self-directed learning, self-reflection, and peer assessment skills required for continuous professional development and precepting students.
column20: Apply the communication, collaboration, and leadership skills gained through teamwork to other professional team environments.
column21: Demonstrate professional attitude and behaviour consistently and work collaboratively with other team members to optimize patientsâ€™ pharmacotherapy outcomes.
column22: Demonstrate respect for diversity of views and experiences.
column23: Embrace self-directed and life-long learning.

column14: Comprehend one and two compartmental models, including the underlying reasons for the appearance of more than one compartment in a plasma concentration vs. time profile.

column14: Describe the components of the healthcare system and how they interrelate as it pertains to the delivery of healthcare services in Canada and more specifically, Alberta.
column15: List the names and describe the function of relevant health professional associations, government agencies, advocacy groups, and private sector players as it pertains to the delivery of health care in Canada with particular emphasis on organizations that impact the profession of pharmacy.
column16: Describe some of the strategies that pharmacists and pharmacy organizations use to influence others within the Canadian healthcare system.
column17: Identify and debate key issues and challenges facing the Canadian healthcare system.
column18: Develop and debate solutions to some of the challenges facing the Canadian healthcare system with emphasis on how pharmacists and pharmacies can be a part of those solutions.
column19: Develop an appreciation for the recommendations made by current (i.e. within the past 10 years) studies, reports and reviews of the Canadian and Albertan health systems.
column20: Develop an appreciation of the different pharmacy service delivery models in different provincial and relevant international jurisdictions.

column2: PHARM 307 Wi18 - DERMATOL/EYE,NOSE,THROAT Combined LAB LEC SEM Wi18
PHARM 307 Wi18 - DERMATOL/EYE,NOSE,THROAT Combined LAB LEC SEM Wi18
column14: Describe the epidemiology, etiology, and risk factors for the conditions of primary focus.
column15: Explain the anatomy of the integumentary system, eye, ear, nose and throat.
column16: Describe the physiology of the skin, eyes, ears, nose and throat.
column17: Explain the physical conditions that lead to skin breakdown and wound development.
column18: Describe the pathophysiology of the primary focus conditions including clinical presentation and symptoms and long term health consequences.
column19: Describe the mechanisms, pathophysiology and clinical presentation of various drug-induced topical reactions.
column20: Relate differences in pharmaceutical vehicles for topical or transdermal drug delivery.
column21: Describe the specific laboratory tests used in the monitoring of isotretinoin.
column22: Describe the therapeutic approach incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments of the primary focus conditions including use of specific target drugs for condition as well as alternative therapies (dose, route of administration, length of therapy, monitoring parameters).
column23: Describe and manage the toxicity of medications used in the management of the primary focus conditions
column24: Describe the societal and economic impact of the primary focus conditions.
column25: Identify ethical issues surrounding treatment of the primary focus conditions
column26: Identify the role and the responsibility of the pharmacist within the course of the disease state and its therapy.
column27: Identify applicable health system resources
column28: For the conditions described the student should:
column29: obtain a relevant history from a patient.
column30: review the presenting signs and symptoms of conditions relating to the skin, eyes, ears, nose and throat.
column31: describe criteria used to make the diagnosis and to be able to relate the severity of the disease.
column32: discuss the therapeutic options with patient, including risks and benefits, and medication and alternative therapy choices
column33: apply and demonstrate appropriate counseling and communication with patients
column34: follow appropriate monitoring parameters
column35: recommend appropriate changes to therapy based on patient outcomes and monitoring parameters
column36: Apply concepts and knowledge of medicinal chemistry, pharmacology and therapeutic principles in selecting and monitoring drug therapy for the management of the primary focus conditions.
column37: Design simple pharmaceutical care plans including alternatives (drug, non-drug, referral, reassurance), recommendations, implementation, monitoring and follow up for patients with the primary focus conditions.
column38: Identify actual and potential drug related problems relating to the primary focus conditions and in various patient cases.
column39: Manage clinically significant drug interactions with drugs used to treat the primary focus conditions.
column40: Demonstrate appropriate physical assessment skills relating to acne, dry skin, eczema and psoriasis.
column41: Refer patients to medical attention as appropriate.
column42: Counsel patients on the use of therapies (non-pharmacologic, Rx and OTC) in the primary focus conditions.
column43: Select appropriate treatment for special groups (pediatrics, elderly, pregnancy, lactation).
column44: Identify when to inform physicians and caregivers if there are danger signs apparent in the assessment.
column45: Recognize the integration of knowledge of therapeutics with medicinal chemistry and pharmacology required to develop rational treatment decisions for therapy, evaluation and monitoring.
column46: Recall, select and apply appropriate knowledge and skills to establish safe and effective drug use.
column47: Utilize an evidence-based approach to therapeutic management of the primary focus conditions.
column48: Apply an evidence-based approach to complementary medicine.
column49: Evaluate and interpret literature with respect to existing and new dosage forms
column50: Identify and locate sources of information needed to solve a problem
column51: Critically evaluate the appropriateness and reliability of information from literature resources
column52: Synthesize information gained from various literature resources to solve problems or make recommendations
column53: Be aware of recent trends in development of new drug delivery systems.
column54: Utilize self-directed learning abilities to synthesize a well-researched review of a non-prescription product.
column55: Interpret scientific literature to make a clinical recommendation.
column56: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for patients experiencing the primary focus conditions.
column57: Work effectively within the healthcare team.
column58: Develop an appreciation of the interdisciplinary nature of patient care
column59: Accept responsibility for keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drugs.

column2: PHARM 342 Wi18 - DRUG USE & PATIENT CARE Combined LAB LEC SEM Wi18
column4: Pharmacy Practice,, BSc in Pharmacy, 1st year
column14: For each component in the patient care process, describe the related activities and responsibilities of pharmacists, pharmacy students, interns, and pharmacy technicians.
column15: Identify legal requirements when accepting/receiving written & verbal prescriptions.
column16: Identify federal and provincial pharmacy legislation with respect to the appropriate handling of drug products and practicing within the professions scope.
column17: Discuss how the medication-dispensing process intersects with the patient care process, and the respective roles of pharmacists, pharmacy students and pharmacy technicians and pharmacy technician students.
column18: Identify the basic process requirements in utilizing the Patient Care Process:
column19: a. Construct a patient care database
column20: b. Identify the drug related problem
column21: c. Manage a patient care profile electronically
column22: Identify and document potential medication prescribing errors in written and verbal prescriptions.
column23: Explain the basic concepts and principles applicable to professional responsibilities in the drug use control process and patient care interactions.
column24: Apply concepts of third party billing and prescription pricing in the drug use process.
column25: Recognize issues surrounding drug diversion and security.
column26: Demonstrate an introductory level of adverse drug reporting and management.
column27: Relate the concepts of the culture of patient safety to the drug use process.
column28: Function efficiently within the simulated pharmacy, both independently and within a group.
column29: Complete an accurate patient record by gathering medication history and other relevant information.
column30: Document search process for drug information questions, citing references used.
column31: Communicate effectively when having a dialogue with a simulated patient and other health care practitioners
column32: Utilize critical thinking in the problem solving process.
column33: Accurately process written and verbal prescriptions, meeting all legal and technical requirements for medications.
column34: Demonstrate competency of the prescription processing software (KROLL).
column35: Apply relevant components of the Patient Care Process model to pharmacy practice.
column36: Demonstrate effective communication in clarifying prescription orders, providing drug information, documentation of errors and interacting with health care professionals and patients.
column37: Demonstrate a responsible, caring, and professional attitude towards the profession of pharmacy, students, patients, and health care professionals.

column20: b. Identify the drug related problem
column21: c. Manage a patient care profile electronically
column22: Identify and document potential medication prescribing errors in written and verbal prescriptions.
column23: Explain the basic concepts and principles applicable to professional responsibilities in the drug use control process and patient care interactions.
column24: Apply concepts of third party billing and prescription pricing in the drug use process.
column25: Function efficiently within the simulated pharmacy, both independently and within a group.
column26: Complete an accurate patient record by gathering medication history and other relevant information.
column27: Document search process for drug information questions, citing references used.
column28: Communicate effectively when having a dialogue with a simulated patient and other health care practitioners
column29: Utilize critical thinking in the problem solving process.
column30: Accurately process written and verbal prescriptions, meeting all legal and technical requirements for medications.
column31: Demonstrate competency of the prescription processing software (KROLL).
column32: Apply relevant components of the Patient Care Process model to pharmacy practice.
column33: Demonstrate effective communication in clarifying prescription orders, providing drug information, documentation of errors and interacting with health care professionals and patients.
column34: Demonstrate a responsible, caring, and professional attitude towards the profession of pharmacy, students, patients, and health care professionals.

column2: PHARM 392 Wi18 - PHARMACOEPIDEMIOLOGY/PRACT RSC Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column4: Pharmacy Practice,, BSc in Pharmacy, 2nd year
column14: Demonstrate critical appraisal skills to assess validity, relevance, and applicability of the pharmacoepidemiologic literature.

column2: PHARM 392 Wi18 - PHARMACOEPIDEMIOLOGY/PRACT RSC Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column4: Pharmacy Practice,, BSc in Pharmacy, 2nd year
column14: Describe the inherent limitations of the drug approval process and pre-marketing clinical trials with regard to assessment of drug safety and effectiveness.
column15: Recognize the difference between type I and type II errors.
column16: Define power and other factors that can influence sample size when trying to detect a difference in risk.
column17: Describe the role of observational studies and randomized controlled trials to support evidence based clinical decisions about safety.
column18: Explain why we need adverse drug reaction reporting systems and why pharmacists should contribute to this process.
column19: Recognize the difference between type A and type B drug reactions and explain which drug reactions are the focus of pharmacoepidemiologic studies.
column20: Define safety signal and explain how it may be generated.
column21: Describe the common data sources used in pharmacoepidemiologic studies. Examples will be presented to highlight the advantages and limitations of each data source.
column22: Describe the major elements of cross-sectional, case-control and cohort studies.
column23: Identify the advantages and limitations of each pharmacoepidemiologic study design. Examples of different studies will be used to illustrate these elements.
column24: Interpret different measures of association reported in pharmacoepidemiologic studies.
column25: Define and interpret effect modification.
column26: Define causal inference.
column27: List Sir Bradford-Hills considerations for inferring causation from observational data.
column28: Classify and describe common types of bias that threaten internal validity of pharmacoepidemiologic studies
column29: Explain how specific biases may affect measures of association.
column30: Define confounding and explain how it can affect the interpretation of an association.
column31: Describe methods used to minimize the effects of confounding in pharmacoepidemiologic studies.
column32: Explain the role of systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
column33: Describe the major elements of a systematic review and meta-analysis.
column34: Explain how we can use pharmacoepidemiologic studies to assess the suspected causal relationship between a drug and an adverse reaction.
column35: Describe the major elements of a quality improvement framework.
column36: Describe the structure-process-outcomes model for evaluating quality of health services.
column37: Define care gap.
column38: Define knowledge translation.
column39: Describe the knowledge-to-action cycle.
column40: Describe different study designs that are commonly used in pharmacy practice research. Examples will be used to illustrate the advantages and limitations of these different study designs.
column41: List common challenges and solutions when integrating research into practice settings.
column42: Explain how the guiding ethical principles from the Tri-Council Policy Statement (TCPS) apply when conducting practice based research.
column43: Describe the major elements of a survey.
column44: Describe how validity of a survey is measured.
column45: Describe the major elements of pharmacoeconomic evaluations.
column46: Demonstrate critical appraisal skills to assess validity, relevance, and applicability of the pharmacoepidemiologic literature.

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column14: Accept responsibility for keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drugs.
column15: Develop an appreciation of the interdisciplinary nature of patient care.
column16: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for patients experiencing of the conditions of primary focus.
column17: Use the principles of evidence-based medicine to critically evaluate the validity and applicability of information from various literature resources.
column18: Identify and retrieve appropriate sources of information needed to resolve drug related problems.
column19: Identify when to inform physicians and caregivers if there are danger signs apparent in the assessment.
column20: Select appropriate treatment for special groups (e.g., pediatrics, geriatrics, pregnant or lactating women).
column21: Identify and resolve clinically significant drug interactions.
column22: Develop a patient care plan related to the care of patients with endocrine disorders, including appropriate monitoring and documentation.
column23: Identify actual and potential drug-related problems associated with pharmacologic management of endocrine disorders.
column24: Apply concepts and knowledge of medicinal chemistry, pharmacology, and therapeutic principles for pharmacologic management of endocrine disorders.
column25: Identify applicable health system resources for the management of endocrine disorders.
column26: Identify the pharmacist's role and the responsibility within the management of endocrine disorders.
column27: Identify ethical and cultural issues surrounding endocrine disorders.
column28: Recognize and understand the appropriate diabetes management strategies for various activities, such as travel, exercise, and acute illness.
column29: Describe the therapeutic approach, incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments to the prevention and management of endocrine disorders; including use of specific target drugs (dose, route of administration, length of therapy, monitoring parameters) for each condition as well as alternative therapies.
column30: Describe actions and adverse effects of common natural health products used to manage endocrine disorders.
column31: Describe the adverse effects of drugs used to manage endocrine disorders.
column32: Apply pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles to the drug treatment of endocrine disorders.
column33: Explain the pharmacologic effects of drugs used to manage endocrine disorders.
column34: Recognize the main structural features of drugs used to manage endocrine disorders.
column35: Describe the specific laboratory tests used in the diagnosis and management of endocrine disorders.
column36: Describe the pathophysiology of endocrine disorders, including clinical presentation, symptomatology, and long-term health consequences.
column37: Describe the epidemiology, etiology, and risk factors of endocrine disorders.
column38: Describe the physiological effects of endocrine hormones.
column39: Identify the main anatomical components of the endocrine system.

column2: PHARM 327 NUTRITION (LEC B1 Wi18)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: By the end of this course, students will be able to develop an appreciation of the fundamental importance of nutrition.
column15: Search and report on a topic of relevance to nutrition and health.
column16: Discuss the criteria of an adequate diet for healthy individuals at various lifecycles (preconception, pregnancy, lactation, infancy, toddler, adolescence, adult and elder).
column17: Discuss dietary management for prophylactic and therapeutic approach of patient care.
column18: Identify healthy diet for prevention and amelioration of chronic diseases inpatient cases.
column19: Explain their learning and knowledge of nutrition to those who are disease state.
column20: Explain how dietary agents (functional foods and nutraceuticals) may preventor delay the onset of some chronic diseases.
column21: Explain the interaction of food and drug.
column22: Explain the interrelation of the biochemical, pharmacological and physiological functions of nutrients.
column23: Understand the application of various tools for nutritional assessment, nutritional deficiencies and toxicities, components of healthy diets, and principles of non-prescription natural health products, functional food regulations, food safety and food processing technologies.
column24: Understand nutritional terminology, dietary requirements, and the role of nutrients in health and disease states, including obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular, osteoporosis, celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, cancer, and autoimmune-inflammatory diseases.

column2: PHARM 447 Fa18 - PSYCHIATRY Combined LEC SEM Fa18
column4: Pharmacy Practice,, BSc in Pharmacy, 3rd year
column14: Develop an appreciation of the interdisciplinary nature of patient care.
column15: Evaluate and apply information from literature and other resources to provide patient care.
column16: Utilize an evidence based approach to therapeutic management of the psychiatric conditions covered.
column17: Manage clinically significant drug interactions with drugs used to treat the psychiatric conditions covered.
column18: Apply principles of therapeutic drug monitoring to deliver patient care, taking into consideration health system and economic factors.
column19: Develop a therapeutic and monitoring plan, taking into consideration patient factors, efficacy, toxicity, cost, route of administration, etc.
column20: Conduct a patient assessment using relevant data from the patient history, review of systems, laboratory tests, diagnostic imaging and medication history in order to provide patient care.
column21: Identify ethical issues in the management of mental health conditions.
column22: Outline the economic and health policy issues as they relate to mental health conditions.
column23: Describe the role of therapeutic drug monitoring for selected medications in the provision of patient care.
column24: Describe the therapeutic approach to managing the conditions covered, including: guideline recommendations and clinical targets, pharmacological (dose, duration of therapy, monitoring parameters), non-pharmacological treatments, and CAM.
column25: Explain the mechanism of action, pharmacokinetic principles, clinical effect(s), and adverse effects and drug interactions for the medication classes covered.
column26: Describe the risk factors, clinical presentation, and assessment parameters (signs and symptoms, laboratory values/tests, physical findings and diagnostic measurements) of the conditions covered.
column27: Outline the epidemiology, etiology and pathophysiology of the mental health conditions covered.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa18)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: To develop a basic understanding of the contemporary diagnostic imaging modalities, including nuclear medicine imaging, x-ray, CT, ultrasound, and MRI, and an understanding of the nature of the clinical information provided by each modality
column15: This course will provide general knowledge regarding diagnostic imaging and radioactivity, and will allow the pharmacist to place a proper perspective on such common concerns in a community as: Radiation safety in general; Biological hazards of radioactive material and installations utilizing radioactivity (eg. xray units) in hospitals and in the community; Risk â€“ benefit concepts in diagnostic imaging; General familiarity with imaging techniques/underlying principles.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa18)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: This module has been designed to familiarize pharmacy students with basic principles of diagnostic imaging, with emphasis on the use of radiation and radioactive drugs and contrast agents in medical diagnosis and therapy. The biological effects of radiation are presented from the viewpoint of a pharmacist's perspective as a health sciences team member.
column15: This course will provide general knowledge regarding diagnostic imaging and radioactivity, and will allow the pharmacist to place a proper perspective on such common concerns in a community as: Radiation safety in general; Biological hazards of radioactive material and installations utilizing radioactivity (eg. xray units) in hospitals and in the community; Risk â€“ benefit concepts in diagnostic imaging; General familiarity with imaging techniques/underlying principles.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa18)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: This module has been designed to familiarize pharmacy students with basic principles of diagnostic imaging, with emphasis on the use of radiation and radioactive drugs and contrast agents in medical diagnosis and therapy. The biological effects of radiation are presented from the viewpoint of a pharmacist's perspective as a health sciences team member.
column15: Following this course, students should be able to interpret the labels on radiopharmaceuticals; perform simple calculations related to radioactive decay.
column16: To consider the various types of radiation and their characteristics and interactions with matter from the viewpoint of how these factors: Influence the utility of different radiations for clinical diagnosis or for therapy; Can present a health hazard from improper use or handling; Determine the methods of radiation detection and measurement
column17: To present the basic principles underlying the biological effects observed with exposure to various levels of radioactivity.
column18: To illustrate the rationale for the use of radioactive drugs and contrast agents for diagnosis by discussing: the various agents presently available from commercial suppliers; the physiological basis of their utility and clinical applications; their formulation and manufacture; methods of quality control and dispensing and inventory control. The use of radioactive drugs for therapy will be examined.
column19: To illustrate "radiopharmaceutical kits", and radionuclide generators for daily preparation of short-lived radiopharmaceuticals in a hospital.
column20: To indicate the levels of radiation dose received from common radiopharmaceutical diagnostic procedures and the inherent dangers with contrast materials and to place these into a benefit vs. risk concept.
column21: To develop a basic understanding of the contemporary diagnostic imaging modalities, including nuclear medicine imaging, x-ray, CT, ultrasound, and MRI, and an understanding of the nature of the clinical information provided by each modality
column22: To acquaint students with basic physical fundamentals regarding concepts of radioactivity, rates and types of radioactive decay; units of radiation; biological effects of radiation â€“ toxicity and therapy; free radical formation and detoxification; diagnostic imaging techniques, instrumentation, and utilization of radiopharmaceuticals.
column23: This course will provide pharmacists with fundamental knowledge of contemporary clinical imaging modalities, including the use of radiopharmaceuticals and contrast agents in clinical diagnosis and therapy. Such a basic understanding will enable pharmacists, as members of a Health Team, to communicate knowledgeably with physicians, nurses, technicians and patients regarding the use of various imaging techniques. Emphasis will be placed on radiopharmaceuticals and contrast agents used with these procedures. The use of radioactive materials for in vitro and in vivo tests, and for radiation therapy, will be addressed. An understanding of the general principles underlying the biologic effects of various levels of radiation will assist the pharmacist in allaying patients' fears and misapprehensions regarding radioactivity.
column24: This course will provide general knowledge regarding diagnostic imaging and radioactivity, and will allow the pharmacist to place a proper perspective on such common concerns in a community as: Radiation safety in general; Biological hazards of radioactive material and installations utilizing radioactivity (eg. xray units) in hospitals and in the community; Risk â€“ benefit concepts in diagnostic imaging; General familiarity with imaging techniques/underlying principles.
column25: This course will provide a basis for further training (either formally or on-the-job) which will provide the expertise for safe and effective handling, preparation and dispensing of radiopharmaceuticals and maintaining proper quality control and inventory.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa18)

column15: To consider the various types of radiation and their characteristics and interactions with matter from the viewpoint of how these factors: Influence the utility of different radiations for clinical diagnosis or for therapy; Can present a health hazard from improper use or handling; Determine the methods of radiation detection and measurement
column16: To present the basic principles underlying the biological effects observed with exposure to various levels of radioactivity.
column17: To indicate the levels of radiation dose received from common radiopharmaceutical diagnostic procedures and the inherent dangers with contrast materials and to place these into a benefit vs. risk concept.
column18: To acquaint students with basic physical fundamentals regarding concepts of radioactivity, rates and types of radioactive decay; units of radiation; biological effects of radiation â€“ toxicity and therapy; free radical formation and detoxification; diagnostic imaging techniques, instrumentation, and utilization of radiopharmaceuticals.

column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: Be sensitive to ethical/legal issues that arise in contemporary pharmacy practice.
column15: Accept possible differences between personal values, morals and rights versus professional obligations and ethics.
column16: Demonstrate caring and respect for others.
column17: Accept the professional responsibility to act for the benefit of the patient.
column18: Demonstrate awareness of the demands of professional, ethical and legal responsibility.
column19: Participate in debating a legal/ethical issue with oneâ€™s peers
column20: Demonstrate ability to distinguish an ethical problem from a legal one, and to identify points of intersection, divergence or confrontation.
column21: Apply actions that a pharmacist can take to avoid ethical breaches and professional discipline
column22: Utilize the problem-solving method (e.g. identify the problem, identify possible alternatives, evaluate the alternatives, choose the best course of action, and defend the action) to integrate ethical and legal principles, and professionalism into pharmacy practice.

column24: Analyze an ethical or legal issue by determining principles involved, clarifying facts, prioritizing principles, assessing alternatives, determining duty and justifying decisions.
column25: Argue both sides of an ethical or legal issue using ethical and legal principles derived from statutes, case law, bioethics literature and the Alberta College of Pharmacists Code of Ethics
column26: Apply legal and ethical principles to issues that may occur in practice.
column27: Describe the course of action taken by the Alberta College of Pharmacists on the issue of substance abuse by pharmacists.
column28: Explain the process of disciplinary action by the Alberta College of Pharmacists.
column29: Describe the court system in the Province of Alberta.
column30: Outline the pharmacists ethical obligations.
column31: Define and explain the following ethical concepts: beneficence, nonmaleficence, autonomy, and informed consent.

column1: PHARM 357 (Fall 2018 LEC A1 SEM E1 E2)
column2: PHARM 357 Fa18 - GASTROINTESTINAL Combined LEC SEM Fa18
column14: Describe the specific laboratory tests and other diagnostic tests used in the diagnosis and monitoring of the conditions of primary focus.
column15: Apply concepts and knowledge of medicinal chemistry, pharmacology and therapeutic principles in selecting and monitoring drug therapy for the conditions of primary focus.
column16: Discuss the complementary and alternative medicine used in GI diseases.
column17: Describe the pathophysiology of the conditions of primary focus including clinical presentations, symptomatology, and complications.
column18: Apply pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles to the treatment of the conditions of primary focus
column19: Describe the epidemiology, etiology, and risk factors of the conditions of primary focus.
column20: Describe the mechanisms, efficacy, side effect profiles and role of each of the following drugs or drug classes: i. Antidiarrheals ii. Laxatives iii. Antinauseants iv. Antiemetics v. Antacids vi. Anti-gas vii. Antispasmodics viii. Drugs Stimulating Gastrointestinal Motility (Prokinetic Agents) ix. Proton-Pump Inhibitors x. H2 receptor antagonists xi. Mucosal protective agents Sucralfate, Prostaglandin analogs (ie misoprostil), Colloidal Bismuth Compounds xii. Antibiotics used for PUD xiii. Aminosalicylates xiv. Corticosteroids used in IBD xv. Immunosuppressants used in IBD (including azathioprine, 6-mercaptopurine, cyclosporine, methotrexate) xvi. Tumour necrosis factor â€“ alpha antagonists (infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab, golimumab) xvii. Pharmacotherapy for complications of cirrhosis (ie diuretics, spironolactone, beta-blockers, octreotide, lactulose, and metronidazole)
column21: Describe the societal and economic impact of the conditions of primary focus.
column22: Identify ethical issues surrounding treatment of the conditions of primary focus
column23: Discuss drugs that can be toxic to the liver
column24: Describe the treatment options for oral health such as canker sores, dry mouth, and mouth care.
column25: Discuss the types of ostomy supplies used by patients with ostomies
column26: Describe the therapeutic approach incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments to the conditions of primary focus, including use of specific target drugs for condition as well as complementary and alternative therapies
column27: Discuss monitoring parameters for each of the disease of focus
column28: Identify actual and potential drug-related problems relating to the conditions of focus and in patient cases.
column29: Select appropriate treatment for special groups (pediatrics, elderly, pregnancy)
column30: Utilize self-directed learning abilities.
column31: Utilize an evidence-based approach to the therapeutic management of the conditions of primary focus, including use of drug, non-drug and complementary and alternative medicines.
column32: Develop an appreciation of the interdisciplinary nature of patient care.
column33: Accept responsibility for keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drugs.

column14: Develop an appreciation of the different pharmacy service delivery models in different provincial and relevant international jurisdictions.
column15: Develop an appreciation for the recommendations made by current (i.e. within the past 10 years) studies, reports and reviews of the Canadian and Albertan health systems.

column17: Identify and debate key issues and challenges facing the Canadian healthcare system.
column18: Describe some of the strategies that pharmacists and pharmacy organizations use to influence others within the Canadian healthcare system.

column20: Describe the components of the healthcare system and how they interrelate as it pertains to the delivery of healthcare services in Canada and more specifically, Alberta.

column2: PHARM 327 Wi19 - NUTRITION Combined LEC Wi19
column14: By the end of this course, students will be able to develop an appreciation of the fundamental importance of nutrition.

column24: Understand nutritional terminology, dietary requirements, and the role of nutrients in health and disease states, including obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular, osteoporosis, celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, cancer, and autoimmune-inflammatory diseases.

column14: Appreciate the challenges related to decision-making and advocacy in grey areas of clinical practice and health.

column18: Use tools to assess medication appropriateness and medication management in seniors.
column19: Describe common stereotypes and biases toward aging in our western society.

column21: Describe the role that culture, religion, and ethnicity may play in health and decision-making.
column22: Briefly describe the psychosocial aspects of aging and be able to explain the role of the pharmacist in dealing with these aspects.
column23: Describe how criteria were developed to classify medications as appropriate or inappropriate in seniors.
column24: Identify medications that are considered inappropriate or high risk in older adults and explain why they are inappropriate or high risk.
column25: Discuss the importance of medication safety and identify measures used to ensure safe medication practices
column26: Identify and describe age-appropriate communication strategies.
column27: Describe the role of pharmacists in the care of pediatric and geriatric patients.
column28: Describe the role of the pharmacist in working with home care.
column29: Identify methods of appropriately communicating with older adults who are hard of hearing.
column30: Contrast how a geriatric syndrome is different than a disease state.
column31: Describe appropriate interventions for falls.
column32: Identify risk factors for falls in older individuals.
column33: Describe the impact of falls on the senior population.

column35: Define polypharmacy and underutilization in terms of medications in seniors.
column36: Contrast disease presentation between the young adult and the elderly adult.

column38: Describe the physiologic alterations associated with normal aging that modify drug response in the elderly patient.

column40: Explain the demographics of aging, and how that may impact society and the healthcare system.
column41: Describe the role of the pharmacist in reducing elder abuse
column42: Identify controversial health issues involving pediatric and geriatric populations
column43: Identify appropriate home care supports for a given patient.
column44: Discuss the role of the pharmacist in medication management of seniors.
column45: List the common geriatric syndromes.
column46: Describe risks for adverse drug events in pediatric and geriatric patients, and explain why they are more susceptible to adverse events.
column47: Describe the use and effect of drugs, pharmacoepidemiology, including prescription, non-prescription medication, and natural health products.
column48: Describe the challenges of providing care in a population with limited evidence.
column49: Categorize the types of abuse commonly suffered by seniors.
